summary.long: Job is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: In the land of Uz there lived a man whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright; he feared God and shunned evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had seven sons and three daughters,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen and five hundred donkeys, and had a large number of servants. He was the greatest man among all the people of the East.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sons used to hold feasts in their homes on their birthdays, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a period of feasting had run its course, Job would make arrangements for them to be purified. Early in the morning he would sacrifice a burnt offering for each of them, thinking, “Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” This was Job’s regular custom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?”
Satan answered the Lord, “From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Does Job fear God for nothing?” Satan replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have you not put a hedge around him and his household and everything he has? You have blessed the work of his hands, so that his flocks and herds are spread throughout the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now stretch out your hand and strike everything he has, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then, everything he has is in your power, but on the man himself do not lay a finger.”
Then Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day when Job’s sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Sabeans attacked and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The fire of God fell from the heavens and burned up the sheep and the servants, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and swept down on your camels and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking, yet another messenger came and said, “Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when suddenly a mighty wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on them and they are dead, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this, Job got up and tore his robe and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground in worship
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and said:
“Naked I came from my mother’s womb,
    and naked I will depart.
The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away;
    may the name of the Lord be praised.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On another day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them to present himself before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And the Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?”
Satan answered the Lord, “From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil. And he still maintains his integrity, though you incited me against him to ruin him without any reason.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Skin for skin!” Satan replied. “A man will give all he has for his own life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then, he is in your hands; but you must spare his life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped himself with it as he sat among the ashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His wife said to him, “Are you still maintaining your integrity? Curse God and die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He replied, “You are talking like a foolish woman. Shall we accept good from God, and not trouble?”
In all this, Job did not sin in what he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Job’s three friends, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, they set out from their homes and met together by agreement to go and sympathize with him and comfort him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him, because they saw how great his suffering was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“May the day of my birth perish,
    and the night that said, ‘A boy is conceived!’
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
May that night be barren;
    may no shout of joy be heard in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May those who curse days curse that day,
    those who are ready to rouse Leviathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
for it did not shut the doors of the womb on me
    to hide trouble from my eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why did I not perish at birth,
    and die as I came from the womb?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why were there knees to receive me
    and breasts that I might be nursed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For now I would be lying down in peace;
    I would be asleep and at rest
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with kings and rulers of the earth,
    who built for themselves places now lying in ruins,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with princes who had gold,
    who filled their houses with silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Or why was I not hidden away in the ground like a stillborn child,
    like an infant who never saw the light of day?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There the wicked cease from turmoil,
    and there the weary are at rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Captives also enjoy their ease;
    they no longer hear the slave driver’s shout.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The small and the great are there,
    and the slaves are freed from their owners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why is light given to those in misery,
    and life to the bitter of soul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to those who long for death that does not come,
    who search for it more than for hidden treasure,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who are filled with gladness
    and rejoice when they reach the grave?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why is life given to a man
    whose way is hidden,
    whom God has hedged in?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For sighing has become my daily food;
    my groans pour out like water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What I feared has come upon me;
    what I dreaded has happened to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have no peace, no quietness;
    I have no rest, but only turmoil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If someone ventures a word with you, will you be impatient?
    But who can keep from speaking?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Think how you have instructed many,
    how you have strengthened feeble hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your words have supported those who stumbled;
    you have strengthened faltering knees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now trouble comes to you, and you are discouraged;
    it strikes you, and you are dismayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Should not your piety be your confidence
    and your blameless ways your hope?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Consider now: Who, being innocent, has ever perished?
    Where were the upright ever destroyed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As I have observed, those who plow evil
    and those who sow trouble reap it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the breath of God they perish;
    at the blast of his anger they are no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lions may roar and growl,
    yet the teeth of the great lions are broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lion perishes for lack of prey,
    and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“A word was secretly brought to me,
    my ears caught a whisper of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amid disquieting dreams in the night,
    when deep sleep falls on people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
fear and trembling seized me
    and made all my bones shake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A spirit glided past my face,
    and the hair on my body stood on end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It stopped,
    but I could not tell what it was.
A form stood before my eyes,
    and I heard a hushed voice:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Can a mortal be more righteous than God?
    Can even a strong man be more pure than his Maker?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If God places no trust in his servants,
    if he charges his angels with error,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
how much more those who live in houses of clay,
    whose foundations are in the dust,
    who are crushed more readily than a moth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Between dawn and dusk they are broken to pieces;
    unnoticed, they perish forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are not the cords of their tent pulled up,
    so that they die without wisdom?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Call if you will, but who will answer you?
    To which of the holy ones will you turn?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Resentment kills a fool,
    and envy slays the simple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I myself have seen a fool taking root,
    but suddenly his house was cursed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His children are far from safety,
    crushed in court without a defender.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The hungry consume his harvest,
    taking it even from among thorns,
    and the thirsty pant after his wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For hardship does not spring from the soil,
    nor does trouble sprout from the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet man is born to trouble
    as surely as sparks fly upward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But if I were you, I would appeal to God;
    I would lay my cause before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed,
    miracles that cannot be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He provides rain for the earth;
    he sends water on the countryside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lowly he sets on high,
    and those who mourn are lifted to safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He thwarts the plans of the crafty,
    so that their hands achieve no success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He catches the wise in their craftiness,
    and the schemes of the wily are swept away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Darkness comes upon them in the daytime;
    at noon they grope as in the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He saves the needy from the sword in their mouth;
    he saves them from the clutches of the powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the poor have hope,
    and injustice shuts its mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Blessed is the one whom God corrects;
    so do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For he wounds, but he also binds up;
    he injures, but his hands also heal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From six calamities he will rescue you;
    in seven no harm will touch you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In famine he will deliver you from death,
    and in battle from the stroke of the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be protected from the lash of the tongue,
    and need not fear when destruction comes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will laugh at destruction and famine,
    and need not fear the wild animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field,
    and the wild animals will be at peace with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will know that your tent is secure;
    you will take stock of your property and find nothing missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will know that your children will be many,
    and your descendants like the grass of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will come to the grave in full vigor,
    like sheaves gathered in season.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“We have examined this, and it is true.
    So hear it and apply it to yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If only my anguish could be weighed
    and all my misery be placed on the scales!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It would surely outweigh the sand of the seas—
    no wonder my words have been impetuous.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Does a wild donkey bray when it has grass,
    or an ox bellow when it has fodder?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is tasteless food eaten without salt,
    or is there flavor in the sap of the mallow?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I refuse to touch it;
    such food makes me ill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Oh, that I might have my request,
    that God would grant what I hope for,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that God would be willing to crush me,
    to let loose his hand and cut off my life!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I would still have this consolation—
    my joy in unrelenting pain—
    that I had not denied the words of the Holy One.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What strength do I have, that I should still hope?
    What prospects, that I should be patient?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do I have the strength of stone?
    Is my flesh bronze?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do I have any power to help myself,
    now that success has been driven from me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Anyone who withholds kindness from a friend
    forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But my brothers are as undependable as intermittent streams,
    as the streams that overflow
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when darkened by thawing ice
    and swollen with melting snow,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but that stop flowing in the dry season,
    and in the heat vanish from their channels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Caravans turn aside from their routes;
    they go off into the wasteland and perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The caravans of Tema look for water,
    the traveling merchants of Sheba look in hope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are distressed, because they had been confident;
    they arrive there, only to be disappointed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now you too have proved to be of no help;
    you see something dreadful and are afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have I ever said, ‘Give something on my behalf,
    pay a ransom for me from your wealth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
deliver me from the hand of the enemy,
    rescue me from the clutches of the ruthless’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Teach me, and I will be quiet;
    show me where I have been wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How painful are honest words!
    But what do your arguments prove?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you mean to correct what I say,
    and treat my desperate words as wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You would even cast lots for the fatherless
    and barter away your friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But now be so kind as to look at me.
    Would I lie to your face?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Relent, do not be unjust;
    reconsider, for my integrity is at stake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is there any wickedness on my lips?
    Can my mouth not discern malice?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do not mortals have hard service on earth?
    Are not their days like those of hired laborers?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a slave longing for the evening shadows,
    or a hired laborer waiting to be paid,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so I have been allotted months of futility,
    and nights of misery have been assigned to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I lie down I think, ‘How long before I get up?’
    The night drags on, and I toss and turn until dawn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My body is clothed with worms and scabs,
    my skin is broken and festering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle,
    and they come to an end without hope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember, O God, that my life is but a breath;
    my eyes will never see happiness again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eye that now sees me will see me no longer;
    you will look for me, but I will be no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a cloud vanishes and is gone,
    so one who goes down to the grave does not return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will never come to his house again;
    his place will know him no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Am I the sea, or the monster of the deep,
    that you put me under guard?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I think my bed will comfort me
    and my couch will ease my complaint,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
even then you frighten me with dreams
    and terrify me with visions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so that I prefer strangling and death,
    rather than this body of mine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I despise my life; I would not live forever.
    Let me alone; my days have no meaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What is mankind that you make so much of them,
    that you give them so much attention,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that you examine them every morning
    and test them every moment?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you never look away from me,
    or let me alone even for an instant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I have sinned, what have I done to you,
    you who see everything we do?
Why have you made me your target?
    Have I become a burden to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you not pardon my offenses
    and forgive my sins?
For I will soon lie down in the dust;
    you will search for me, but I will be no more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How long will you say such things?
    Your words are a blustering wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does God pervert justice?
    Does the Almighty pervert what is right?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When your children sinned against him,
    he gave them over to the penalty of their sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if you will seek God earnestly
    and plead with the Almighty,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Your beginnings will seem humble,
    so prosperous will your future be.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Ask the former generation
    and find out what their ancestors learned,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for we were born only yesterday and know nothing,
    and our days on earth are but a shadow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will they not instruct you and tell you?
    Will they not bring forth words from their understanding?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can papyrus grow tall where there is no marsh?
    Can reeds thrive without water?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While still growing and uncut,
    they wither more quickly than grass.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Such is the destiny of all who forget God;
    so perishes the hope of the godless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What they trust in is fragile;
    what they rely on is a spider’s web.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They lean on the web, but it gives way;
    they cling to it, but it does not hold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are like a well-watered plant in the sunshine,
    spreading its shoots over the garden;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
it entwines its roots around a pile of rocks
    and looks for a place among the stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But when it is torn from its spot,
    that place disowns it and says, ‘I never saw you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely its life withers away,
    and from the soil other plants grow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Surely God does not reject one who is blameless
    or strengthen the hands of evildoers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will yet fill your mouth with laughter
    and your lips with shouts of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your enemies will be clothed in shame,
    and the tents of the wicked will be no more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Indeed, I know that this is true.
    But how can mere mortals prove their innocence before God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though they wished to dispute with him,
    they could not answer him one time out of a thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His wisdom is profound, his power is vast.
    Who has resisted him and come out unscathed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He moves mountains without their knowing it
    and overturns them in his anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He shakes the earth from its place
    and makes its pillars tremble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He speaks to the sun and it does not shine;
    he seals off the light of the stars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He alone stretches out the heavens
    and treads on the waves of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is the Maker of the Bear and Orion,
    the Pleiades and the constellations of the south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed,
    miracles that cannot be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he passes me, I cannot see him;
    when he goes by, I cannot perceive him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If he snatches away, who can stop him?
    Who can say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God does not restrain his anger;
    even the cohorts of Rahab cowered at his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How then can I dispute with him?
    How can I find words to argue with him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though I were innocent, I could not answer him;
    I could only plead with my Judge for mercy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if I summoned him and he responded,
    I do not believe he would give me a hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He would crush me with a storm
    and multiply my wounds for no reason.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He would not let me catch my breath
    but would overwhelm me with misery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If it is a matter of strength, he is mighty!
    And if it is a matter of justice, who can challenge him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if I were innocent, my mouth would condemn me;
    if I were blameless, it would pronounce me guilty.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
It is all the same; that is why I say,
    ‘He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When a scourge brings sudden death,
    he mocks the despair of the innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When a land falls into the hands of the wicked,
    he blindfolds its judges.
    If it is not he, then who is it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My days are swifter than a runner;
    they fly away without a glimpse of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They skim past like boats of papyrus,
    like eagles swooping down on their prey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint,
    I will change my expression, and smile,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I still dread all my sufferings,
    for I know you will not hold me innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Since I am already found guilty,
    why should I struggle in vain?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if I washed myself with soap
    and my hands with cleansing powder,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
you would plunge me into a slime pit
    so that even my clothes would detest me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He is not a mere mortal like me that I might answer him,
    that we might confront each other in court.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If only there were someone to mediate between us,
    someone to bring us together,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
someone to remove God’s rod from me,
    so that his terror would frighten me no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I would speak up without fear of him,
    but as it now stands with me, I cannot.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I say to God: Do not declare me guilty,
    but tell me what charges you have against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does it please you to oppress me,
    to spurn the work of your hands,
    while you smile on the plans of the wicked?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you have eyes of flesh?
    Do you see as a mortal sees?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are your days like those of a mortal
    or your years like those of a strong man,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that you must search out my faults
    and probe after my sin—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
though you know that I am not guilty
    and that no one can rescue me from your hand?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Your hands shaped me and made me.
    Will you now turn and destroy me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember that you molded me like clay.
    Will you now turn me to dust again?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did you not pour me out like milk
    and curdle me like cheese,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
clothe me with skin and flesh
    and knit me together with bones and sinews?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You gave me life and showed me kindness,
    and in your providence watched over my spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But this is what you concealed in your heart,
    and I know that this was in your mind:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I sinned, you would be watching me
    and would not let my offense go unpunished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I am guilty—woe to me!
    Even if I am innocent, I cannot lift my head,
for I am full of shame
    and drowned in my affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I hold my head high, you stalk me like a lion
    and again display your awesome power against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Why then did you bring me out of the womb?
    I wish I had died before any eye saw me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If only I had never come into being,
    or had been carried straight from the womb to the grave!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are not my few days almost over?
    Turn away from me so I can have a moment’s joy
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
before I go to the place of no return,
    to the land of gloom and utter darkness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to the land of deepest night,
    of utter darkness and disorder,
    where even the light is like darkness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zophar the Naamathite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Are all these words to go unanswered?
    Is this talker to be vindicated?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will your idle talk reduce others to silence?
    Will no one rebuke you when you mock?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You say to God, ‘My beliefs are flawless
    and I am pure in your sight.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, how I wish that God would speak,
    that he would open his lips against you
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and disclose to you the secrets of wisdom,
    for true wisdom has two sides.
    Know this: God has even forgotten some of your sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Can you fathom the mysteries of God?
    Can you probe the limits of the Almighty?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are higher than the heavens above—what can you do?
    They are deeper than the depths below—what can you know?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their measure is longer than the earth
    and wider than the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If he comes along and confines you in prison
    and convenes a court, who can oppose him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely he recognizes deceivers;
    and when he sees evil, does he not take note?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the witless can no more become wise
    than a wild donkey’s colt can be born human.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Yet if you devote your heart to him
    and stretch out your hands to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if you put away the sin that is in your hand
    and allow no evil to dwell in your tent,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then, free of fault, you will lift up your face;
    you will stand firm and without fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will surely forget your trouble,
    recalling it only as waters gone by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Life will be brighter than noonday,
    and darkness will become like morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be secure, because there is hope;
    you will look about you and take your rest in safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will lie down, with no one to make you afraid,
    and many will court your favor.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Doubtless you are the only people who matter,
    and wisdom will die with you!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“I have become a laughingstock to my friends,
    though I called on God and he answered—
    a mere laughingstock, though righteous and blameless!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who are at ease have contempt for misfortune
    as the fate of those whose feet are slipping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The tents of marauders are undisturbed,
    and those who provoke God are secure—
    those God has in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But ask the animals, and they will teach you,
    or the birds in the sky, and they will tell you;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
or speak to the earth, and it will teach you,
    or let the fish in the sea inform you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Which of all these does not know
    that the hand of the Lord has done this?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In his hand is the life of every creature
    and the breath of all mankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does not the ear test words
    as the tongue tastes food?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is not wisdom found among the aged?
    Does not long life bring understanding?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“To God belong wisdom and power;
    counsel and understanding are his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What he tears down cannot be rebuilt;
    those he imprisons cannot be released.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If he holds back the waters, there is drought;
    if he lets them loose, they devastate the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To him belong strength and insight;
    both deceived and deceiver are his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He leads rulers away stripped
    and makes fools of judges.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He takes off the shackles put on by kings
    and ties a loincloth around their waist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He leads priests away stripped
    and overthrows officials long established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He silences the lips of trusted advisers
    and takes away the discernment of elders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He pours contempt on nobles
    and disarms the mighty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He reveals the deep things of darkness
    and brings utter darkness into the light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes nations great, and destroys them;
    he enlarges nations, and disperses them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He deprives the leaders of the earth of their reason;
    he makes them wander in a trackless waste.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They grope in darkness with no light;
    he makes them stagger like drunkards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My eyes have seen all this,
    my ears have heard and understood it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What you know, I also know;
    I am not inferior to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I desire to speak to the Almighty
    and to argue my case with God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You, however, smear me with lies;
    you are worthless physicians, all of you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If only you would be altogether silent!
    For you, that would be wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear now my argument;
    listen to the pleas of my lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you speak wickedly on God’s behalf?
    Will you speak deceitfully for him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you show him partiality?
    Will you argue the case for God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would it turn out well if he examined you?
    Could you deceive him as you might deceive a mortal?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He would surely call you to account
    if you secretly showed partiality.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would not his splendor terrify you?
    Would not the dread of him fall on you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your maxims are proverbs of ashes;
    your defenses are defenses of clay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Keep silent and let me speak;
    then let come to me what may.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do I put myself in jeopardy
    and take my life in my hands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though he slay me, yet will I hope in him;
    I will surely defend my ways to his face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, this will turn out for my deliverance,
    for no godless person would dare come before him!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen carefully to what I say;
    let my words ring in your ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now that I have prepared my case,
    I know I will be vindicated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can anyone bring charges against me?
    If so, I will be silent and die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Only grant me these two things, God,
    and then I will not hide from you:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Withdraw your hand far from me,
    and stop frightening me with your terrors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then summon me and I will answer,
    or let me speak, and you reply to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How many wrongs and sins have I committed?
    Show me my offense and my sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you hide your face
    and consider me your enemy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you torment a windblown leaf?
    Will you chase after dry chaff?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For you write down bitter things against me
    and make me reap the sins of my youth.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“So man wastes away like something rotten,
    like a garment eaten by moths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Mortals, born of woman,
    are of few days and full of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They spring up like flowers and wither away;
    like fleeting shadows, they do not endure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you fix your eye on them?
    Will you bring them before you for judgment?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can bring what is pure from the impure?
    No one!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
So look away from him and let him alone,
    till he has put in his time like a hired laborer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“At least there is hope for a tree:
    If it is cut down, it will sprout again,
    and its new shoots will not fail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its roots may grow old in the ground
    and its stump die in the soil,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
yet at the scent of water it will bud
    and put forth shoots like a plant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But a man dies and is laid low;
    he breathes his last and is no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the water of a lake dries up
    or a riverbed becomes parched and dry,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“If only you would hide me in the grave
    and conceal me till your anger has passed!
If only you would set me a time
    and then remember me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If someone dies, will they live again?
    All the days of my hard service
    I will wait for my renewal to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will call and I will answer you;
    you will long for the creature your hands have made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely then you will count my steps
    but not keep track of my sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My offenses will be sealed up in a bag;
    you will cover over my sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But as a mountain erodes and crumbles
    and as a rock is moved from its place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
as water wears away stones
    and torrents wash away the soil,
    so you destroy a person’s hope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You overpower them once for all, and they are gone;
    you change their countenance and send them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If their children are honored, they do not know it;
    if their offspring are brought low, they do not see it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They feel but the pain of their own bodies
    and mourn only for themselves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Would a wise person answer with empty notions
    or fill their belly with the hot east wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would they argue with useless words,
    with speeches that have no value?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you even undermine piety
    and hinder devotion to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your sin prompts your mouth;
    you adopt the tongue of the crafty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your own mouth condemns you, not mine;
    your own lips testify against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Are you the first man ever born?
    Were you brought forth before the hills?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you listen in on God’s council?
    Do you have a monopoly on wisdom?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What do you know that we do not know?
    What insights do you have that we do not have?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The gray-haired and the aged are on our side,
    men even older than your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are God’s consolations not enough for you,
    words spoken gently to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why has your heart carried you away,
    and why do your eyes flash,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so that you vent your rage against God
    and pour out such words from your mouth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What are mortals, that they could be pure,
    or those born of woman, that they could be righteous?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If God places no trust in his holy ones,
    if even the heavens are not pure in his eyes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
how much less mortals, who are vile and corrupt,
    who drink up evil like water!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Listen to me and I will explain to you;
    let me tell you what I have seen,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
what the wise have declared,
    hiding nothing received from their ancestors
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
(to whom alone the land was given
    when no foreigners moved among them):
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All his days the wicked man suffers torment,
    the ruthless man through all the years stored up for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terrifying sounds fill his ears;
    when all seems well, marauders attack him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He despairs of escaping the realm of darkness;
    he is marked for the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He wanders about for food like a vulture;
    he knows the day of darkness is at hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Distress and anguish fill him with terror;
    troubles overwhelm him, like a king poised to attack,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because he shakes his fist at God
    and vaunts himself against the Almighty,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
defiantly charging against him
    with a thick, strong shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Though his face is covered with fat
    and his waist bulges with flesh,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he will inhabit ruined towns
    and houses where no one lives,
    houses crumbling to rubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will no longer be rich and his wealth will not endure,
    nor will his possessions spread over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Let him not deceive himself by trusting what is worthless,
    for he will get nothing in return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before his time he will wither,
    and his branches will not flourish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will be like a vine stripped of its unripe grapes,
    like an olive tree shedding its blossoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the company of the godless will be barren,
    and fire will consume the tents of those who love bribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They conceive trouble and give birth to evil;
    their womb fashions deceit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I have heard many things like these;
    you are miserable comforters, all of you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will your long-winded speeches never end?
    What ails you that you keep on arguing?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I also could speak like you,
    if you were in my place;
I could make fine speeches against you
    and shake my head at you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But my mouth would encourage you;
    comfort from my lips would bring you relief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Yet if I speak, my pain is not relieved;
    and if I refrain, it does not go away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely, God, you have worn me out;
    you have devastated my entire household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have shriveled me up—and it has become a witness;
    my gauntness rises up and testifies against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
God has turned me over to the ungodly
    and thrown me into the clutches of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
his archers surround me.
Without pity, he pierces my kidneys
    and spills my gall on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Again and again he bursts upon me;
    he rushes at me like a warrior.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I have sewed sackcloth over my skin
    and buried my brow in the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My face is red with weeping,
    dark shadows ring my eyes;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
yet my hands have been free of violence
    and my prayer is pure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Earth, do not cover my blood;
    may my cry never be laid to rest!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even now my witness is in heaven;
    my advocate is on high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My intercessor is my friend
    as my eyes pour out tears to God;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
on behalf of a man he pleads with God
    as one pleads for a friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Only a few years will pass
    before I take the path of no return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My spirit is broken,
    my days are cut short,
    the grave awaits me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely mockers surround me;
    my eyes must dwell on their hostility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Give me, O God, the pledge you demand.
    Who else will put up security for me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have closed their minds to understanding;
    therefore you will not let them triumph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If anyone denounces their friends for reward,
    the eyes of their children will fail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“God has made me a byword to everyone,
    a man in whose face people spit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My eyes have grown dim with grief;
    my whole frame is but a shadow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The upright are appalled at this;
    the innocent are aroused against the ungodly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nevertheless, the righteous will hold to their ways,
    and those with clean hands will grow stronger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But come on, all of you, try again!
    I will not find a wise man among you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My days have passed, my plans are shattered.
    Yet the desires of my heart
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
turn night into day;
    in the face of the darkness light is near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If the only home I hope for is the grave,
    if I spread out my bed in the realm of darkness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I say to corruption, ‘You are my father,’
    and to the worm, ‘My mother’ or ‘My sister,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
where then is my hope—
    who can see any hope for me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will it go down to the gates of death?
    Will we descend together into the dust?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When will you end these speeches?
    Be sensible, and then we can talk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why are we regarded as cattle
    and considered stupid in your sight?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who tear yourself to pieces in your anger,
    is the earth to be abandoned for your sake?
    Or must the rocks be moved from their place?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The lamp of a wicked man is snuffed out;
    the flame of his fire stops burning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The light in his tent becomes dark;
    the lamp beside him goes out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The vigor of his step is weakened;
    his own schemes throw him down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His feet thrust him into a net;
    he wanders into its mesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A trap seizes him by the heel;
    a snare holds him fast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A noose is hidden for him on the ground;
    a trap lies in his path.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terrors startle him on every side
    and dog his every step.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Calamity is hungry for him;
    disaster is ready for him when he falls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It eats away parts of his skin;
    death’s firstborn devours his limbs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is torn from the security of his tent
    and marched off to the king of terrors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fire resides in his tent;
    burning sulfur is scattered over his dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His roots dry up below
    and his branches wither above.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The memory of him perishes from the earth;
    he has no name in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is driven from light into the realm of darkness
    and is banished from the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has no offspring or descendants among his people,
    no survivor where once he lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People of the west are appalled at his fate;
    those of the east are seized with horror.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely such is the dwelling of an evil man;
    such is the place of one who does not know God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How long will you torment me
    and crush me with words?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ten times now you have reproached me;
    shamelessly you attack me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If it is true that I have gone astray,
    my error remains my concern alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If indeed you would exalt yourselves above me
    and use my humiliation against me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then know that God has wronged me
    and drawn his net around me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Though I cry, ‘Violence!’ I get no response;
    though I call for help, there is no justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has blocked my way so I cannot pass;
    he has shrouded my paths in darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has stripped me of my honor
    and removed the crown from my head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He tears me down on every side till I am gone;
    he uproots my hope like a tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His anger burns against me;
    he counts me among his enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“He has alienated my family from me;
    my acquaintances are completely estranged from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My relatives have gone away;
    my closest friends have forgotten me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My guests and my female servants count me a foreigner;
    they look on me as on a stranger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I summon my servant, but he does not answer,
    though I beg him with my own mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My breath is offensive to my wife;
    I am loathsome to my own family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even the little boys scorn me;
    when I appear, they ridicule me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All my intimate friends detest me;
    those I love have turned against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am nothing but skin and bones;
    I have escaped only by the skin of my teeth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Have pity on me, my friends, have pity,
    for the hand of God has struck me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you pursue me as God does?
    Will you never get enough of my flesh?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Oh, that my words were recorded,
    that they were written on a scroll,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that they were inscribed with an iron tool on lead,
    or engraved in rock forever!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know that my redeemer lives,
    and that in the end he will stand on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And after my skin has been destroyed,
    yet in my flesh I will see God;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I myself will see him
    with my own eyes—I, and not another.
    How my heart yearns within me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If you say, ‘How we will hound him,
    since the root of the trouble lies in him,’
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then Zophar the Naamathite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My troubled thoughts prompt me to answer
    because I am greatly disturbed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I hear a rebuke that dishonors me,
    and my understanding inspires me to reply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Surely you know how it has been from of old,
    ever since mankind was placed on the earth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that the mirth of the wicked is brief,
    the joy of the godless lasts but a moment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though the pride of the godless person reaches to the heavens
    and his head touches the clouds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he will perish forever, like his own dung;
    those who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a dream he flies away, no more to be found,
    banished like a vision of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eye that saw him will not see him again;
    his place will look on him no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His children must make amends to the poor;
    his own hands must give back his wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The youthful vigor that fills his bones
    will lie with him in the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Though evil is sweet in his mouth
    and he hides it under his tongue,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
though he cannot bear to let it go
    and lets it linger in his mouth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
yet his food will turn sour in his stomach;
    it will become the venom of serpents within him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will spit out the riches he swallowed;
    God will make his stomach vomit them up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will suck the poison of serpents;
    the fangs of an adder will kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will not enjoy the streams,
    the rivers flowing with honey and cream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What he toiled for he must give back uneaten;
    he will not enjoy the profit from his trading.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For he has oppressed the poor and left them destitute;
    he has seized houses he did not build.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Surely he will have no respite from his craving;
    he cannot save himself by his treasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nothing is left for him to devour;
    his prosperity will not endure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the midst of his plenty, distress will overtake him;
    the full force of misery will come upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he has filled his belly,
    God will vent his burning anger against him
    and rain down his blows on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though he flees from an iron weapon,
    a bronze-tipped arrow pierces him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
total darkness lies in wait for his treasures.
A fire unfanned will consume him
    and devour what is left in his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heavens will expose his guilt;
    the earth will rise up against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A flood will carry off his house,
    rushing waters on the day of God’s wrath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Such is the fate God allots the wicked,
    the heritage appointed for them by God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Listen carefully to my words;
    let this be the consolation you give me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bear with me while I speak,
    and after I have spoken, mock on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is my complaint directed to a human being?
    Why should I not be impatient?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at me and be appalled;
    clap your hand over your mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I think about this, I am terrified;
    trembling seizes my body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do the wicked live on,
    growing old and increasing in power?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They see their children established around them,
    their offspring before their eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their homes are safe and free from fear;
    the rod of God is not on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their bulls never fail to breed;
    their cows calve and do not miscarry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They send forth their children as a flock;
    their little ones dance about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They sing to the music of timbrel and lyre;
    they make merry to the sound of the pipe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They spend their years in prosperity
    and go down to the grave in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet they say to God, ‘Leave us alone!
    We have no desire to know your ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him?
    What would we gain by praying to him?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But their prosperity is not in their own hands,
    so I stand aloof from the plans of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Yet how often is the lamp of the wicked snuffed out?
    How often does calamity come upon them,
    the fate God allots in his anger?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How often are they like straw before the wind,
    like chaff swept away by a gale?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is said, ‘God stores up the punishment of the wicked for their children.’
    Let him repay the wicked, so that they themselves will experience it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let their own eyes see their destruction;
    let them drink the cup of the wrath of the Almighty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For what do they care about the families they leave behind
    when their allotted months come to an end?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Can anyone teach knowledge to God,
    since he judges even the highest?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One person dies in full vigor,
    completely secure and at ease,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
well nourished in body,
    bones rich with marrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Another dies in bitterness of soul,
    never having enjoyed anything good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Side by side they lie in the dust,
    and worms cover them both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I know full well what you are thinking,
    the schemes by which you would wrong me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You say, ‘Where now is the house of the great,
    the tents where the wicked lived?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you never questioned those who travel?
    Have you paid no regard to their accounts—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that the wicked are spared from the day of calamity,
    that they are delivered from the day of wrath?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who denounces their conduct to their face?
    Who repays them for what they have done?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are carried to the grave,
    and watch is kept over their tombs.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“So how can you console me with your nonsense?
    Nothing is left of your answers but falsehood!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Can a man be of benefit to God?
    Can even a wise person benefit him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What pleasure would it give the Almighty if you were righteous?
    What would he gain if your ways were blameless?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is it for your piety that he rebukes you
    and brings charges against you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is not your wickedness great?
    Are not your sins endless?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You demanded security from your relatives for no reason;
    you stripped people of their clothing, leaving them naked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You gave no water to the weary
    and you withheld food from the hungry,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
though you were a powerful man, owning land—
    an honored man, living on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And you sent widows away empty-handed
    and broke the strength of the fatherless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why snares are all around you,
    why sudden peril terrifies you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
why it is so dark you cannot see,
    and why a flood of water covers you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is not God in the heights of heaven?
    And see how lofty are the highest stars!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet you say, ‘What does God know?
    Does he judge through such darkness?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Thick clouds veil him, so he does not see us
    as he goes about in the vaulted heavens.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you keep to the old path
    that the wicked have trod?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They were carried off before their time,
    their foundations washed away by a flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They said to God, ‘Leave us alone!
    What can the Almighty do to us?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet it was he who filled their houses with good things,
    so I stand aloof from the plans of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The righteous see their ruin and rejoice;
    the innocent mock them, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Surely our foes are destroyed,
    and fire devours their wealth.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Submit to God and be at peace with him;
    in this way prosperity will come to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Accept instruction from his mouth
    and lay up his words in your heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored:
    If you remove wickedness far from your tent
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and assign your nuggets to the dust,
    your gold of Ophir to the rocks in the ravines,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then the Almighty will be your gold,
    the choicest silver for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely then you will find delight in the Almighty
    and will lift up your face to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will pray to him, and he will hear you,
    and you will fulfill your vows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What you decide on will be done,
    and light will shine on your ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When people are brought low and you say, ‘Lift them up!’
    then he will save the downcast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will deliver even one who is not innocent,
    who will be delivered through the cleanness of your hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Even today my complaint is bitter;
    his hand is heavy in spite of my groaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If only I knew where to find him;
    if only I could go to his dwelling!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would state my case before him
    and fill my mouth with arguments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would find out what he would answer me,
    and consider what he would say to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would he vigorously oppose me?
    No, he would not press charges against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There the upright can establish their innocence before him,
    and there I would be delivered forever from my judge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But if I go to the east, he is not there;
    if I go to the west, I do not find him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he is at work in the north, I do not see him;
    when he turns to the south, I catch no glimpse of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But he knows the way that I take;
    when he has tested me, I will come forth as gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My feet have closely followed his steps;
    I have kept to his way without turning aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have not departed from the commands of his lips;
    I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But he stands alone, and who can oppose him?
    He does whatever he pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He carries out his decree against me,
    and many such plans he still has in store.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I am terrified before him;
    when I think of all this, I fear him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God has made my heart faint;
    the Almighty has terrified me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet I am not silenced by the darkness,
    by the thick darkness that covers my face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why does the Almighty not set times for judgment?
    Why must those who know him look in vain for such days?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are those who move boundary stones;
    they pasture flocks they have stolen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They drive away the orphan’s donkey
    and take the widow’s ox in pledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They thrust the needy from the path
    and force all the poor of the land into hiding.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
They gather fodder in the fields
    and glean in the vineyards of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lacking clothes, they spend the night naked;
    they have nothing to cover themselves in the cold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are drenched by mountain rains
    and hug the rocks for lack of shelter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fatherless child is snatched from the breast;
    the infant of the poor is seized for a debt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lacking clothes, they go about naked;
    they carry the sheaves, but still go hungry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They crush olives among the terraces;
    they tread the winepresses, yet suffer thirst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The groans of the dying rise from the city,
    and the souls of the wounded cry out for help.
    But God charges no one with wrongdoing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“There are those who rebel against the light,
    who do not know its ways
    or stay in its paths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When daylight is gone, the murderer rises up,
    kills the poor and needy,
    and in the night steals forth like a thief.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For all of them, midnight is their morning;
    they make friends with the terrors of darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
As heat and drought snatch away the melted snow,
    so the grave snatches away those who have sinned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The womb forgets them,
    the worm feasts on them;
the wicked are no longer remembered
    but are broken like a tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They prey on the barren and childless woman,
    and to the widow they show no kindness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But God drags away the mighty by his power;
    though they become established, they have no assurance of life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He may let them rest in a feeling of security,
    but his eyes are on their ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“If this is not so, who can prove me false
    and reduce my words to nothing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Dominion and awe belong to God;
    he establishes order in the heights of heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can his forces be numbered?
    On whom does his light not rise?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How then can a mortal be righteous before God?
    How can one born of woman be pure?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If even the moon is not bright
    and the stars are not pure in his eyes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
how much less a mortal, who is but a maggot—
    a human being, who is only a worm!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How you have helped the powerless!
    How you have saved the arm that is feeble!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What advice you have offered to one without wisdom!
    And what great insight you have displayed!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has helped you utter these words?
    And whose spirit spoke from your mouth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The dead are in deep anguish,
    those beneath the waters and all that live in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The realm of the dead is naked before God;
    Destruction lies uncovered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He spreads out the northern skies over empty space;
    he suspends the earth over nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He wraps up the waters in his clouds,
    yet the clouds do not burst under their weight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He covers the face of the full moon,
    spreading his clouds over it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He marks out the horizon on the face of the waters
    for a boundary between light and darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The pillars of the heavens quake,
    aghast at his rebuke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By his power he churned up the sea;
    by his wisdom he cut Rahab to pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By his breath the skies became fair;
    his hand pierced the gliding serpent.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: And Job continued his discourse:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“As surely as God lives, who has denied me justice,
    the Almighty, who has made my life bitter,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
as long as I have life within me,
    the breath of God in my nostrils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
my lips will not say anything wicked,
    and my tongue will not utter lies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will never admit you are in the right;
    till I die, I will not deny my integrity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will maintain my innocence and never let go of it;
    my conscience will not reproach me as long as I live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“May my enemy be like the wicked,
    my adversary like the unjust!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For what hope have the godless when they are cut off,
    when God takes away their life?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does God listen to their cry
    when distress comes upon them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will they find delight in the Almighty?
    Will they call on God at all times?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will teach you about the power of God;
    the ways of the Almighty I will not conceal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have all seen this yourselves.
    Why then this meaningless talk?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Here is the fate God allots to the wicked,
    the heritage a ruthless man receives from the Almighty:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However many his children, their fate is the sword;
    his offspring will never have enough to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The plague will bury those who survive him,
    and their widows will not weep for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though he heaps up silver like dust
    and clothes like piles of clay,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
what he lays up the righteous will wear,
    and the innocent will divide his silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The house he builds is like a moth’s cocoon,
    like a hut made by a watchman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He lies down wealthy, but will do so no more;
    when he opens his eyes, all is gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terrors overtake him like a flood;
    a tempest snatches him away in the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The east wind carries him off, and he is gone;
    it sweeps him out of his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It hurls itself against him without mercy
    as he flees headlong from its power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It claps its hands in derision
    and hisses him out of his place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a mine for silver
    and a place where gold is refined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Iron is taken from the earth,
    and copper is smelted from ore.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The earth, from which food comes,
    is transformed below as by fire;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
lapis lazuli comes from its rocks,
    and its dust contains nuggets of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No bird of prey knows that hidden path,
    no falcon’s eye has seen it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Proud beasts do not set foot on it,
    and no lion prowls there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People assault the flinty rock with their hands
    and lay bare the roots of the mountains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They tunnel through the rock;
    their eyes see all its treasures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They search the sources of the rivers
    and bring hidden things to light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But where can wisdom be found?
    Where does understanding dwell?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No mortal comprehends its worth;
    it cannot be found in the land of the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The deep says, “It is not in me”;
    the sea says, “It is not with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It cannot be bought with the finest gold,
    nor can its price be weighed out in silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It cannot be bought with the gold of Ophir,
    with precious onyx or lapis lazuli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Neither gold nor crystal can compare with it,
    nor can it be had for jewels of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Coral and jasper are not worthy of mention;
    the price of wisdom is beyond rubies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The topaz of Cush cannot compare with it;
    it cannot be bought with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where then does wisdom come from?
    Where does understanding dwell?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is hidden from the eyes of every living thing,
    concealed even from the birds in the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Destruction and Death say,
    “Only a rumor of it has reached our ears.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God understands the way to it
    and he alone knows where it dwells,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for he views the ends of the earth
    and sees everything under the heavens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he established the force of the wind
    and measured out the waters,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when he made a decree for the rain
    and a path for the thunderstorm,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then he looked at wisdom and appraised it;
    he confirmed it and tested it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And he said to the human race,
    “The fear of the Lord—that is wisdom,
    and to shun evil is understanding.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Job continued his discourse:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How I long for the months gone by,
    for the days when God watched over me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when his lamp shone on my head
    and by his light I walked through darkness!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, for the days when I was in my prime,
    when God’s intimate friendship blessed my house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when the Almighty was still with me
    and my children were around me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when my path was drenched with cream
    and the rock poured out for me streams of olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When I went to the gate of the city
    and took my seat in the public square,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the young men saw me and stepped aside
    and the old men rose to their feet;
verses.speaker: Narrator
