verses.text:
the chief men refrained from speaking
    and covered their mouths with their hands;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the voices of the nobles were hushed,
    and their tongues stuck to the roof of their mouths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever heard me spoke well of me,
    and those who saw me commended me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because I rescued the poor who cried for help,
    and the fatherless who had none to assist them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The one who was dying blessed me;
    I made the widow’s heart sing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I put on righteousness as my clothing;
    justice was my robe and my turban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was eyes to the blind
    and feet to the lame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was a father to the needy;
    I took up the case of the stranger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I broke the fangs of the wicked
    and snatched the victims from their teeth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I thought, ‘I will die in my own house,
    my days as numerous as the grains of sand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My roots will reach to the water,
    and the dew will lie all night on my branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My glory will not fade;
    the bow will be ever new in my hand.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“People listened to me expectantly,
    waiting in silence for my counsel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After I had spoken, they spoke no more;
    my words fell gently on their ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They waited for me as for showers
    and drank in my words as the spring rain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I smiled at them, they scarcely believed it;
    the light of my face was precious to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“But now they mock me,
    men younger than I,
whose fathers I would have disdained
    to put with my sheep dogs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Of what use was the strength of their hands to me,
    since their vigor had gone from them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Haggard from want and hunger,
    they roamed the parched land
    in desolate wastelands at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the brush they gathered salt herbs,
    and their food was the root of the broom bush.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They were banished from human society,
    shouted at as if they were thieves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They were forced to live in the dry stream beds,
    among the rocks and in holes in the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They brayed among the bushes
    and huddled in the undergrowth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A base and nameless brood,
    they were driven out of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And now those young men mock me in song;
    I have become a byword among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They detest me and keep their distance;
    they do not hesitate to spit in my face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now that God has unstrung my bow and afflicted me,
    they throw off restraint in my presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
They advance as through a gaping breach;
    amid the ruins they come rolling in.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“And now my life ebbs away;
    days of suffering grip me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Night pierces my bones;
    my gnawing pains never rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In his great power God becomes like clothing to me;
    he binds me like the neck of my garment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He throws me into the mud,
    and I am reduced to dust and ashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I cry out to you, God, but you do not answer;
    I stand up, but you merely look at me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You turn on me ruthlessly;
    with the might of your hand you attack me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You snatch me up and drive me before the wind;
    you toss me about in the storm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know you will bring me down to death,
    to the place appointed for all the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Surely no one lays a hand on a broken man
    when he cries for help in his distress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have I not wept for those in trouble?
    Has not my soul grieved for the poor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet when I hoped for good, evil came;
    when I looked for light, then came darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The churning inside me never stops;
    days of suffering confront me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I go about blackened, but not by the sun;
    I stand up in the assembly and cry for help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have become a brother of jackals,
    a companion of owls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My skin grows black and peels;
    my body burns with fever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My lyre is tuned to mourning,
    and my pipe to the sound of wailing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I made a covenant with my eyes
    not to look lustfully at a young woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For what is our lot from God above,
    our heritage from the Almighty on high?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is it not ruin for the wicked,
    disaster for those who do wrong?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does he not see my ways
    and count my every step?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If I have walked with falsehood
    or my foot has hurried after deceit—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
let God weigh me in honest scales
    and he will know that I am blameless—
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
then may others eat what I have sown,
    and may my crops be uprooted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If my heart has been enticed by a woman,
    or if I have lurked at my neighbor’s door,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then may my wife grind another man’s grain,
    and may other men sleep with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For that would have been wicked,
    a sin to be judged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is a fire that burns to Destruction;
    it would have uprooted my harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If I have denied justice to any of my servants,
    whether male or female,
    when they had a grievance against me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
what will I do when God confronts me?
    What will I answer when called to account?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did not he who made me in the womb make them?
    Did not the same one form us both within our mothers?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If I have denied the desires of the poor
    or let the eyes of the widow grow weary,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have kept my bread to myself,
    not sharing it with the fatherless—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but from my youth I reared them as a father would,
    and from my birth I guided the widow—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have seen anyone perishing for lack of clothing,
    or the needy without garments,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and their hearts did not bless me
    for warming them with the fleece from my sheep,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have raised my hand against the fatherless,
    knowing that I had influence in court,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then let my arm fall from the shoulder,
    let it be broken off at the joint.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For I dreaded destruction from God,
    and for fear of his splendor I could not do such things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If I have put my trust in gold
    or said to pure gold, ‘You are my security,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have rejoiced over my great wealth,
    the fortune my hands had gained,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have regarded the sun in its radiance
    or the moon moving in splendor,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so that my heart was secretly enticed
    and my hand offered them a kiss of homage,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then these also would be sins to be judged,
    for I would have been unfaithful to God on high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If I have rejoiced at my enemy’s misfortune
    or gloated over the trouble that came to him—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have not allowed my mouth to sin
    by invoking a curse against their life—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if those of my household have never said,
    ‘Who has not been filled with Job’s meat?’—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but no stranger had to spend the night in the street,
    for my door was always open to the traveler—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have concealed my sin as people do,
    by hiding my guilt in my heart
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because I so feared the crowd
    and so dreaded the contempt of the clans
    that I kept silent and would not go outside—
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Surely I would wear it on my shoulder,
    I would put it on like a crown.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would give him an account of my every step;
    I would present it to him as to a ruler.)—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“if my land cries out against me
    and all its furrows are wet with tears,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have devoured its yield without payment
    or broken the spirit of its tenants,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then let briers come up instead of wheat
    and stinkweed instead of barley.”
The words of Job are ended.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So these three men stopped answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job for justifying himself rather than God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was also angry with the three friends, because they had found no way to refute Job, and yet had condemned him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Elihu had waited before speaking to Job because they were older than he.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he saw that the three men had nothing more to say, his anger was aroused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite said:
“I am young in years,
    and you are old;
that is why I was fearful,
    not daring to tell you what I know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I thought, ‘Age should speak;
    advanced years should teach wisdom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But it is the spirit in a person,
    the breath of the Almighty, that gives them understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not only the old who are wise,
    not only the aged who understand what is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Therefore I say: Listen to me;
    I too will tell you what I know.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not say, ‘We have found wisdom;
    let God, not a man, refute him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Job has not marshaled his words against me,
    and I will not answer him with your arguments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They are dismayed and have no more to say;
    words have failed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Must I wait, now that they are silent,
    now that they stand there with no reply?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I too will have my say;
    I too will tell what I know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For I am full of words,
    and the spirit within me compels me;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
inside I am like bottled-up wine,
    like new wineskins ready to burst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I must speak and find relief;
    I must open my lips and reply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will show no partiality,
    nor will I flatter anyone;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for if I were skilled in flattery,
    my Maker would soon take me away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But now, Job, listen to my words;
    pay attention to everything I say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am about to open my mouth;
    my words are on the tip of my tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My words come from an upright heart;
    my lips sincerely speak what I know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Spirit of God has made me;
    the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Answer me then, if you can;
    stand up and argue your case before me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am the same as you in God’s sight;
    I too am a piece of clay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No fear of me should alarm you,
    nor should my hand be heavy on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But you have said in my hearing—
    I heard the very words—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘I am pure, I have done no wrong;
    I am clean and free from sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet God has found fault with me;
    he considers me his enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He fastens my feet in shackles;
    he keeps close watch on all my paths.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But I tell you, in this you are not right,
    for God is greater than any mortal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you complain to him
    that he responds to no one’s words?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For God does speak—now one way, now another—
    though no one perceives it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In a dream, in a vision of the night,
    when deep sleep falls on people
    as they slumber in their beds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he may speak in their ears
    and terrify them with warnings,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to turn them from wrongdoing
    and keep them from pride,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to preserve them from the pit,
    their lives from perishing by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Or someone may be chastened on a bed of pain
    with constant distress in their bones,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so that their body finds food repulsive
    and their soul loathes the choicest meal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their flesh wastes away to nothing,
    and their bones, once hidden, now stick out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They draw near to the pit,
    and their life to the messengers of death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet if there is an angel at their side,
    a messenger, one out of a thousand,
    sent to tell them how to be upright,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
let their flesh be renewed like a child’s;
    let them be restored as in the days of their youth’—
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
And they will go to others and say,
    ‘I have sinned, I have perverted what is right,
    but I did not get what I deserved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God has delivered me from going down to the pit,
    and I shall live to enjoy the light of life.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“God does all these things to a person—
    twice, even three times—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to turn them back from the pit,
    that the light of life may shine on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Pay attention, Job, and listen to me;
    be silent, and I will speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you have anything to say, answer me;
    speak up, for I want to vindicate you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if not, then listen to me;
    be silent, and I will teach you wisdom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elihu said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Hear my words, you wise men;
    listen to me, you men of learning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the ear tests words
    as the tongue tastes food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let us discern for ourselves what is right;
    let us learn together what is good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Job says, ‘I am innocent,
    but God denies me justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although I am right,
    I am considered a liar;
although I am guiltless,
    his arrow inflicts an incurable wound.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is there anyone like Job,
    who drinks scorn like water?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He keeps company with evildoers;
    he associates with the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For he says, ‘There is no profit
    in trying to please God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“So listen to me, you men of understanding.
    Far be it from God to do evil,
    from the Almighty to do wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He repays everyone for what they have done;
    he brings on them what their conduct deserves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is unthinkable that God would do wrong,
    that the Almighty would pervert justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who appointed him over the earth?
    Who put him in charge of the whole world?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If it were his intention
    and he withdrew his spirit and breath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
all humanity would perish together
    and mankind would return to the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If you have understanding, hear this;
    listen to what I say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can someone who hates justice govern?
    Will you condemn the just and mighty One?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is he not the One who says to kings, ‘You are worthless,’
    and to nobles, ‘You are wicked,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who shows no partiality to princes
    and does not favor the rich over the poor,
    for they are all the work of his hands?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“His eyes are on the ways of mortals;
    he sees their every step.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no deep shadow, no utter darkness,
    where evildoers can hide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God has no need to examine people further,
    that they should come before him for judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Without inquiry he shatters the mighty
    and sets up others in their place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because he takes note of their deeds,
    he overthrows them in the night and they are crushed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He punishes them for their wickedness
    where everyone can see them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because they turned from following him
    and had no regard for any of his ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They caused the cry of the poor to come before him,
    so that he heard the cry of the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if he remains silent, who can condemn him?
    If he hides his face, who can see him?
Yet he is over individual and nation alike,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to keep the godless from ruling,
    from laying snares for the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Suppose someone says to God,
    ‘I am guilty but will offend no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Teach me what I cannot see;
    if I have done wrong, I will not do so again.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Should God then reward you on your terms,
    when you refuse to repent?
You must decide, not I;
    so tell me what you know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Men of understanding declare,
    wise men who hear me say to me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Job speaks without knowledge;
    his words lack insight.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, that Job might be tested to the utmost
    for answering like a wicked man!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then Elihu said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do you think this is just?
    You say, ‘I am in the right, not God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet you ask him, ‘What profit is it to me,
    and what do I gain by not sinning?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I would like to reply to you
    and to your friends with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look up at the heavens and see;
    gaze at the clouds so high above you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you sin, how does that affect him?
    If your sins are many, what does that do to him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you are righteous, what do you give to him,
    or what does he receive from your hand?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your wickedness only affects humans like yourself,
    and your righteousness only other people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“People cry out under a load of oppression;
    they plead for relief from the arm of the powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker,
    who gives songs in the night,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who teaches us more than he teaches the beasts of the earth
    and makes us wiser than the birds in the sky?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does not answer when people cry out
    because of the arrogance of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, God does not listen to their empty plea;
    the Almighty pays no attention to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How much less, then, will he listen
    when you say that you do not see him,
that your case is before him
    and you must wait for him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and further, that his anger never punishes
    and he does not take the least notice of wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Job opens his mouth with empty talk;
    without knowledge he multiplies words.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elihu continued:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Bear with me a little longer and I will show you
    that there is more to be said in God’s behalf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I get my knowledge from afar;
    I will ascribe justice to my Maker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be assured that my words are not false;
    one who has perfect knowledge is with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“God is mighty, but despises no one;
    he is mighty, and firm in his purpose.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does not keep the wicked alive
    but gives the afflicted their rights.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
But if people are bound in chains,
    held fast by cords of affliction,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he tells them what they have done—
    that they have sinned arrogantly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes them listen to correction
    and commands them to repent of their evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If they obey and serve him,
    they will spend the rest of their days in prosperity
    and their years in contentment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if they do not listen,
    they will perish by the sword
    and die without knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The godless in heart harbor resentment;
    even when he fetters them, they do not cry for help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They die in their youth,
    among male prostitutes of the shrines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But those who suffer he delivers in their suffering;
    he speaks to them in their affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He is wooing you from the jaws of distress
    to a spacious place free from restriction,
    to the comfort of your table laden with choice food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now you are laden with the judgment due the wicked;
    judgment and justice have taken hold of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be careful that no one entices you by riches;
    do not let a large bribe turn you aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would your wealth or even all your mighty efforts
    sustain you so you would not be in distress?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not long for the night,
    to drag people away from their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Beware of turning to evil,
    which you seem to prefer to affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“God is exalted in his power.
    Who is a teacher like him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has prescribed his ways for him,
    or said to him, ‘You have done wrong’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember to extol his work,
    which people have praised in song.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All humanity has seen it;
    mortals gaze on it from afar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How great is God—beyond our understanding!
    The number of his years is past finding out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He draws up the drops of water,
    which distill as rain to the streams;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the clouds pour down their moisture
    and abundant showers fall on mankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can understand how he spreads out the clouds,
    how he thunders from his pavilion?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
See how he scatters his lightning about him,
    bathing the depths of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the way he governs the nations
    and provides food in abundance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He fills his hands with lightning
    and commands it to strike its mark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His thunder announces the coming storm;
    even the cattle make known its approach.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“At this my heart pounds
    and leaps from its place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen! Listen to the roar of his voice,
    to the rumbling that comes from his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He unleashes his lightning beneath the whole heaven
    and sends it to the ends of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After that comes the sound of his roar;
    he thunders with his majestic voice.
When his voice resounds,
    he holds nothing back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God’s voice thunders in marvelous ways;
    he does great things beyond our understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He says to the snow, ‘Fall on the earth,’
    and to the rain shower, ‘Be a mighty downpour.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So that everyone he has made may know his work,
    he stops all people from their labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The animals take cover;
    they remain in their dens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The tempest comes out from its chamber,
    the cold from the driving winds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The breath of God produces ice,
    and the broad waters become frozen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He loads the clouds with moisture;
    he scatters his lightning through them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At his direction they swirl around
    over the face of the whole earth
    to do whatever he commands them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brings the clouds to punish people,
    or to water his earth and show his love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Listen to this, Job;
    stop and consider God’s wonders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you know how God controls the clouds
    and makes his lightning flash?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you know how the clouds hang poised,
    those wonders of him who has perfect knowledge?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who swelter in your clothes
    when the land lies hushed under the south wind,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
can you join him in spreading out the skies,
    hard as a mirror of cast bronze?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Tell us what we should say to him;
    we cannot draw up our case because of our darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Should he be told that I want to speak?
    Would anyone ask to be swallowed up?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now no one can look at the sun,
    bright as it is in the skies
    after the wind has swept them clean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Out of the north he comes in golden splendor;
    God comes in awesome majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Almighty is beyond our reach and exalted in power;
    in his justice and great righteousness, he does not oppress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, people revere him,
    for does he not have regard for all the wise in heart?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm. He said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who is this that obscures my plans
    with words without knowledge?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Where were you when I laid the earth’s foundation?
    Tell me, if you understand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who marked off its dimensions? Surely you know!
    Who stretched a measuring line across it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On what were its footings set,
    or who laid its cornerstone—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
while the morning stars sang together
    and all the angels shouted for joy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who shut up the sea behind doors
    when it burst forth from the womb,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when I made the clouds its garment
    and wrapped it in thick darkness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when I fixed limits for it
    and set its doors and bars in place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when I said, ‘This far you may come and no farther;
    here is where your proud waves halt’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Have you ever given orders to the morning,
    or shown the dawn its place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that it might take the earth by the edges
    and shake the wicked out of it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth takes shape like clay under a seal;
    its features stand out like those of a garment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked are denied their light,
    and their upraised arm is broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Have you journeyed to the springs of the sea
    or walked in the recesses of the deep?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have the gates of death been shown to you?
    Have you seen the gates of the deepest darkness?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you comprehended the vast expanses of the earth?
    Tell me, if you know all this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What is the way to the abode of light?
    And where does darkness reside?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you take them to their places?
    Do you know the paths to their dwellings?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely you know, for you were already born!
    You have lived so many years!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Have you entered the storehouses of the snow
    or seen the storehouses of the hail,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
which I reserve for times of trouble,
    for days of war and battle?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is the way to the place where the lightning is dispersed,
    or the place where the east winds are scattered over the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who cuts a channel for the torrents of rain,
    and a path for the thunderstorm,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to water a land where no one lives,
    an uninhabited desert,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to satisfy a desolate wasteland
    and make it sprout with grass?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does the rain have a father?
    Who fathers the drops of dew?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From whose womb comes the ice?
    Who gives birth to the frost from the heavens
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when the waters become hard as stone,
    when the surface of the deep is frozen?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades?
    Can you loosen Orion’s belt?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you bring forth the constellations in their seasons
    or lead out the Bear with its cubs?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you know the laws of the heavens?
    Can you set up God’s dominion over the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Can you raise your voice to the clouds
    and cover yourself with a flood of water?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you send the lightning bolts on their way?
    Do they report to you, ‘Here we are’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who gives the ibis wisdom
    or gives the rooster understanding?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has the wisdom to count the clouds?
    Who can tip over the water jars of the heavens
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when the dust becomes hard
    and the clods of earth stick together?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do you hunt the prey for the lioness
    and satisfy the hunger of the lions
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when they crouch in their dens
    or lie in wait in a thicket?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who provides food for the raven
    when its young cry out to God
    and wander about for lack of food?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do you know when the mountain goats give birth?
    Do you watch when the doe bears her fawn?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you count the months till they bear?
    Do you know the time they give birth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They crouch down and bring forth their young;
    their labor pains are ended.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their young thrive and grow strong in the wilds;
    they leave and do not return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who let the wild donkey go free?
    Who untied its ropes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I gave it the wasteland as its home,
    the salt flats as its habitat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It laughs at the commotion in the town;
    it does not hear a driver’s shout.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It ranges the hills for its pasture
    and searches for any green thing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Will the wild ox consent to serve you?
    Will it stay by your manger at night?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you hold it to the furrow with a harness?
    Will it till the valleys behind you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you rely on it for its great strength?
    Will you leave your heavy work to it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you trust it to haul in your grain
    and bring it to your threshing floor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The wings of the ostrich flap joyfully,
    though they cannot compare
    with the wings and feathers of the stork.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She lays her eggs on the ground
    and lets them warm in the sand,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
unmindful that a foot may crush them,
    that some wild animal may trample them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She treats her young harshly, as if they were not hers;
    she cares not that her labor was in vain,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for God did not endow her with wisdom
    or give her a share of good sense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet when she spreads her feathers to run,
    she laughs at horse and rider.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do you give the horse its strength
    or clothe its neck with a flowing mane?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you make it leap like a locust,
    striking terror with its proud snorting?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It paws fiercely, rejoicing in its strength,
    and charges into the fray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It laughs at fear, afraid of nothing;
    it does not shy away from the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The quiver rattles against its side,
    along with the flashing spear and lance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In frenzied excitement it eats up the ground;
    it cannot stand still when the trumpet sounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the blast of the trumpet it snorts, ‘Aha!’
    It catches the scent of battle from afar,
    the shout of commanders and the battle cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Does the hawk take flight by your wisdom
    and spread its wings toward the south?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does the eagle soar at your command
    and build its nest on high?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It dwells on a cliff and stays there at night;
    a rocky crag is its stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From there it looks for food;
    its eyes detect it from afar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its young ones feast on blood,
    and where the slain are, there it is.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Job:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Will the one who contends with the Almighty correct him?
    Let him who accuses God answer him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job answered the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I am unworthy—how can I reply to you?
    I put my hand over my mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I spoke once, but I have no answer—
    twice, but I will say no more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Would you discredit my justice?
    Would you condemn me to justify yourself?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you have an arm like God’s,
    and can your voice thunder like his?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then adorn yourself with glory and splendor,
    and clothe yourself in honor and majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Unleash the fury of your wrath,
    look at all who are proud and bring them low,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
look at all who are proud and humble them,
    crush the wicked where they stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bury them all in the dust together;
    shroud their faces in the grave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I myself will admit to you
    that your own right hand can save you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Look at Behemoth,
    which I made along with you
    and which feeds on grass like an ox.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What strength it has in its loins,
    what power in the muscles of its belly!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its tail sways like a cedar;
    the sinews of its thighs are close-knit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its bones are tubes of bronze,
    its limbs like rods of iron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It ranks first among the works of God,
    yet its Maker can approach it with his sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The hills bring it their produce,
    and all the wild animals play nearby.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Under the lotus plants it lies,
    hidden among the reeds in the marsh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lotuses conceal it in their shadow;
    the poplars by the stream surround it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A raging river does not alarm it;
    it is secure, though the Jordan should surge against its mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can anyone capture it by the eyes,
    or trap it and pierce its nose?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Can you pull in Leviathan with a fishhook
    or tie down its tongue with a rope?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you put a cord through its nose
    or pierce its jaw with a hook?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will it keep begging you for mercy?
    Will it speak to you with gentle words?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will it make an agreement with you
    for you to take it as your slave for life?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you make a pet of it like a bird
    or put it on a leash for the young women in your house?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will traders barter for it?
    Will they divide it up among the merchants?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you fill its hide with harpoons
    or its head with fishing spears?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you lay a hand on it,
    you will remember the struggle and never do it again!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Any hope of subduing it is false;
    the mere sight of it is overpowering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one is fierce enough to rouse it.
    Who then is able to stand against me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has a claim against me that I must pay?
    Everything under heaven belongs to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will not fail to speak of Leviathan’s limbs,
    its strength and its graceful form.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can strip off its outer coat?
    Who can penetrate its double coat of armor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who dares open the doors of its mouth,
    ringed about with fearsome teeth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its back has rows of shields
    tightly sealed together;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
each is so close to the next
    that no air can pass between.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are joined fast to one another;
    they cling together and cannot be parted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its snorting throws out flashes of light;
    its eyes are like the rays of dawn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flames stream from its mouth;
    sparks of fire shoot out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Smoke pours from its nostrils
    as from a boiling pot over burning reeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its breath sets coals ablaze,
    and flames dart from its mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strength resides in its neck;
    dismay goes before it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The folds of its flesh are tightly joined;
    they are firm and immovable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its chest is hard as rock,
    hard as a lower millstone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When it rises up, the mighty are terrified;
    they retreat before its thrashing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sword that reaches it has no effect,
    nor does the spear or the dart or the javelin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Iron it treats like straw
    and bronze like rotten wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Arrows do not make it flee;
    slingstones are like chaff to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A club seems to it but a piece of straw;
    it laughs at the rattling of the lance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its undersides are jagged potsherds,
    leaving a trail in the mud like a threshing sledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It makes the depths churn like a boiling caldron
    and stirs up the sea like a pot of ointment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It leaves a glistening wake behind it;
    one would think the deep had white hair.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nothing on earth is its equal—
    a creature without fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It looks down on all that are haughty;
    it is king over all that are proud.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job replied to the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I know that you can do all things;
    no purpose of yours can be thwarted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You asked, ‘Who is this that obscures my plans without knowledge?’
    Surely I spoke of things I did not understand,
    things too wonderful for me to know.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
My ears had heard of you
    but now my eyes have seen you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore I despise myself
    and repent in dust and ashes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Lord had said these things to Job, he said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “I am angry with you and your two friends, because you have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now take seven bulls and seven rams and go to my servant Job and sacrifice a burnt offering for yourselves. My servant Job will pray for you, and I will accept his prayer and not deal with you according to your folly. You have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite did what the Lord told them; and the Lord accepted Job’s prayer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Job had prayed for his friends, the Lord restored his fortunes and gave him twice as much as he had before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his brothers and sisters and everyone who had known him before came and ate with him in his house. They comforted and consoled him over all the trouble the Lord had brought on him, and each one gave him a piece of silver and a gold ring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord blessed the latter part of Job’s life more than the former part. He had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, a thousand yoke of oxen and a thousand donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he also had seven sons and three daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first daughter he named Jemimah, the second Keziah and the third Keren-Happuch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nowhere in all the land were there found women as beautiful as Job’s daughters, and their father granted them an inheritance along with their brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Job lived a hundred and forty years; he saw his children and their children to the fourth generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so Job died, an old man and full of years.
verses.speaker: Narrator
